_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Applicable building, electrical, and plumbing codes. The facility complies with the Iowa Fertilizer Law
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: The portions of the codes that were utilized are those deemed applicable by the jurisdiction
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vandalism, theft; vehicular protection, potential leakage from underground piping
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Breakaway couplers at the riser and remote emergency shut off valve at the storage tank
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Regular plant inspection/ routine preventative maintainence and repair
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Pumps, pump seals, pipes and plumbing, valves, electrical and safety equipment, breakaway couplers, pressure relief valves, and hoses are inspected and replaced as neccessary
_prev_prog_2.Description: The Plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidentalreleases on NH3. Employees working at the storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of the NH3 from the storage vessels to the nurse tanks. In doing so, they are able to detect potential problems prior to them occurring. This routine inspection identifies any external portion of the system which may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before they become problematic. Employees are annually trained to recognize the hazards associated with NH3 including the storage and handling of NH3. In addition to annual training for long term employees, the company conducts new hire training which includes hazard material training via classroom instruction, onsite training at the plant, and follow up observation to determine comprehension of training. The company has certain employee(s) participating in annual HazWoper training and invites local fire department personnel to visit the site. In the event that local fire department requests assistance in training its employees/volunteers on NH3, the company cooperates fully.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention/Emergency Response at Two Rivers Cooperative, Pella IA

This facility complies with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1989 requirements for Anhydrous Ammonia storage. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and local regulations. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the Mahaska and Marion County Emergency Management Agencies as Tracy is located near the border of both counties. A 911 call would be made to both organizations. Incidental to the notification to the  County EMAs, a call to Marion and Mahaska County LEPA will be made.



Two Rivers has planned for an emergency, it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be unexpected and may very well be much different than the scenarios anticipated and cannot be ensured to duplicate the defined plan. In reality, the situation that develops may not occur in the manner planned or assumed, in that instance, the plan will be utilized as a guideline.



The Emergency Action plan (EAP) developed for the facility describes procedures that are intended to minimize hazards associated with human health and environment from fires, explosions, sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (NH3), tornadoes, bomb threats, theft, or other accidents and acts of natures that may occur on our premises.

The primary emergency coordinator for the Tracy, Iowa location is Nick Steinbach, Safety Coordinator. Nick Steinbach's  work and 24-hour contact information are provided in the registration section of this document. In addition, the following individuals are to be contacted in the order listed:



Craig Hetland

Work: 641-949-6411

Cell: 641-218-4089

Home: 641-628-9815



Jim Findley

Cell: 641-891-0580



Matt Van Weelden

Work: 641-627-5311

Cell: 641-780-1999

Home: 641-627-5288



Description of the Anhydrous Ammonia Storage/Distribution Plant and the regulated Substance Handled at Two Rivers Cooperative:

This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia (NH3) storage an

d distribution plant. The NH3 that is stored at the facility is distributed to agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize the product for crop nutrient purposes.



The system consists of one (1) large storage tank with associated piping, valves, liquid pumps and other miscellaneous equipment. Throughout the year numerous portable nurse tanks may also be present at the site. The NH3 plant is only operated on a seasonal basis (Spring and Fall). Full time equivalent employees were computed on that basis. At a maximum, the plant operates a total of three (3) months. The FTE for the location is two (2).





The Worst Case Scenarios and Alternative Release Scenarios:

The worst scenario is the failure of one storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed (85% of capacity), resulting n the release of the total volume in a gaseous (hazardous ammonia vapor cloud) form. According the EPA eRMP Program the distance to endpoint is 4.4 miles.



The alternative release scenario involves the transport delivery vehicle pulling away from the intake lines into the storage plant without disconnecting the hoses. The resulting release, according  to the EPA's eRMP Program has a distance end point of 0.5 miles.



The system shut off is protected by internal excess flow valves, check valves, relief valves, manual shut off valves, and emergency shut off valves. The load out risers used in filling nurse tanks area protected by breakaway couplers designed to immediately stop the flow of ammonia if the line or hose breaks. All of the main storage tank valves are to be locked when not in use.



As the facility is located in relatively close proximity of the town of Tracy, IA and the Red Rock Reservoir, provisions have been designed to affected persons and an evacuation plan is in place in case of major incident.





General accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps:

This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule

and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. The Anhydrous Ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1989 with amendments and State of Iowa law.



In addition, the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental and potentially catastrophic release of anhydrous ammonia. Finally, Two Rivers Cooperative has extended to all local EMA and Fire Departments the opportunity to visit the location and to avail themselves of specific anhydrous ammonia health hazard information and training.





Five-Year Accident History:

Two Rivers Cooperative has not experienced any accidental release involving anhydrous ammonia in the last five years that caused death, injury, property or environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering's.





The Emergency Response Program:

In the event of an emergency involving the Tracy anhydrous ammonia system, it is the policy of Two Rivers Cooperative to immediately notify the Tracy Volunteer Fire Department and the Mahaska and Marion EMA to request that they respond to the emergency at the Tracy location. In the unlikely event the Tracy Volunteer Department in unable to adequately respond to an emergency, the Pella Fire Department will be summoned due to a reciprocal agreement with Tracy. Members of Two Rivers Cooperative management have discussed these procedures with leaders of the emergency personnel involved. Members of the fire department and the LEPC have inspected the Tracy location and copies of photographs of the plant have been provided for reference purposes to the entities.





Planned changes to improve safety:

The plan is to minimize hazards to human health and the environment that are associated with an accidental release of NH3. Employees working at the plant make routine observations prior to and during the transfer operations of product. In doing so, they are able to detect any potential issues. The routin

e inspections identify any portion of the system that may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made prior to an incident. Employees are annually trained and new hires are also trained as described in this document. Training is also available to local emergency responders as described earlier in the document.
